description: From Middle English balowe, balwe, balgh, from Old English bælg, bæliġ (“bag, purse, leathern bottle, pair of bellows, pod, husk”), from Proto-Germanic *balgiz (“bag”). Doublet of belly, bellows, and bulge.

adjectives.description: ballow (comparative more ballow, superlative most ballow)

examples: A horse of greater speed, nor yet a righter hound,
Not any where twixt Kent and Calidon is found.
Nor yet the levell South can shewe a smoother Race,
Whereas the ballow Nag out-strips the winds in chase;

entries.meaning: (nautical) Deep water inside a shoal or bar.
